content.thinking:
Perfect! I can see the desktop file. To run it as admin/root on Linux, I need to modify the Exec lines to use a privilege escalation tool. Common options are:
- `pkexec` (PolicyKit)
- `sudo` (but this typically requires a terminal)
- `kdesu` or `gksu` (depending on desktop environment)

Since this is a GUI application, `pkexec` is probably the best choice. I'll need to:
1. Copy the system desktop file to the user's local applications directory (so we don't modify the system file)
2. Modify the Exec lines to use pkexec

Let me create a local copy and modify it.

content.thinking:
The issue is that running GUI apps with sudo requires passing the X11/Wayland authentication properly. The `-E` flag preserves environment variables, but root still can't connect to the user's X/Wayland session without proper authorization.

I need to update the wrapper to properly handle the X authority. Let me create a better wrapper that:
1. Preserves the DISPLAY variable
2. Allows root to access the X server using xhost or by preserving XAUTHORITY
3. For Wayland, we might need different handling

Let me update the wrapper script with better display server handling.

input.new_string:
#!/bin/bash
# Wrapper to run Antigravity as admin with proper environment

# Preserve display variables and X authority
export DISPLAY="${DISPLAY:-:0}"
export XAUTHORITY="${XAUTHORITY:-$HOME/.Xauthority}"
export WAYLAND_DISPLAY="${WAYLAND_DISPLAY}"
export XDG_RUNTIME_DIR="${XDG_RUNTIME_DIR}"

# Run with sudo, preserving environment
sudo -E DISPLAY="$DISPLAY" XAUTHORITY="$XAUTHORITY" WAYLAND_DISPLAY="$WAYLAND_DISPLAY" XDG_RUNTIME_DIR="$XDG_RUNTIME_DIR" /opt/Antigravity/antigravity "$@"

content.text: Actually, the issue is that root needs explicit permission to access your display server. Let me update the wrapper to handle this properly:

input.old_string:
#!/bin/bash
# Wrapper to run Antigravity as admin with proper environment

# Preserve display variables and X authority
export DISPLAY="${DISPLAY:-:0}"
export XAUTHORITY="${XAUTHORITY:-$HOME/.Xauthority}"
export WAYLAND_DISPLAY="${WAYLAND_DISPLAY}"
export XDG_RUNTIME_DIR="${XDG_RUNTIME_DIR}"

# Run with sudo, preserving environment
sudo -E DISPLAY="$DISPLAY" XAUTHORITY="$XAUTHORITY" WAYLAND_DISPLAY="$WAYLAND_DISPLAY" XDG_RUNTIME_DIR="$XDG_RUNTIME_DIR" /opt/Antigravity/antigravity "$@"
input.new_string:
#!/bin/bash
# Wrapper to run Antigravity as admin with proper environment

# Grant root access to X server temporarily
xhost +SI:localuser:root >/dev/null 2>&1

# Run with sudo, preserving display environment
sudo DISPLAY="$DISPLAY" XAUTHORITY="$XAUTHORITY" WAYLAND_DISPLAY="$WAYLAND_DISPLAY" XDG_RUNTIME_DIR="$XDG_RUNTIME_DIR" /opt/Antigravity/antigravity "$@"

# Revoke root access to X server
xhost -SI:localuser:root >/dev/null 2>&1

content.content:
Web search results for query: "COSMIC desktop screenshot keyboard shortcut selective area clipboard [REDACTED_PHONE]"

Links: [{"title":"Closing in on a COSMIC Alpha - System76 Blog","url":"https://blog.system76.com/post/closing-in-on-a-cosmic-alpha/"},{"title":"Custom keyboard shortcuts don't work · Issue #[REDACTED_PHONE] · pop-os/cosmic-epoch","url":"https://github.com/pop-os/cosmic-epoch/issues/[REDACTED_PHONE]"},{"title":"Pop!_OS [REDACTED_PHONE] LTS COSMIC Keyboard Shortcuts - System76 Support","url":"https://support.system76.com/articles/pop-cosmic-keyboard-shortcuts/"},{"title":"COSMIC UX","url":"https://system76.com/cosmic/ux"},{"title":"New and More Screenshot and Screen Recording Keyboard Shortcuts Now Available! – Awesome Screenshot Blog","url":"https://blog.awesomescreenshot.com/[REDACTED_PHONE]/06/05/new-and-more-screenshot-screen-recording-keyboard-shortcuts-now-available/"},{"title":"Add keyboard shortcut for copying screenshot of an area to clipboard · Issue #249 · pop-os/cosmic","url":"https://github.com/pop-os/cosmic/issues/249"},{"title":"Keyboard Shortcuts | pop-os/cosmic-files | DeepWiki","url":"https://deepwiki.com/pop-os/cosmic-files/4.3-keyboard-shortcuts"},{"title":"Cosmic Desktop Alpha Release - Mikeserv Support Forum","url":"https://mikeserv.com/support/viewtopic.php?t=175"},{"title":"Alpha 3: Tales from the COSMIC Desktop Environment - System76 Blog","url":"https://blog.system76.com/post/cosmic-alpha-3/"},{"title":"COSMIC keyboard navigation and management system · Issue #46 · pop-os/cosmic-epoch","url":"https://github.com/pop-os/cosmic-epoch/issues/46"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about COSMIC desktop screenshot keyboard shortcuts for selective area to clipboard:

## Screenshot Functionality

COSMIC's screenshot tool can take screenshots of the entire screen, a specific window, or a selected area.

## Keyboard Shortcuts

There is an existing default hotkey: shift + ctrl + print for screenshot functionality, though this was noted as inconvenient.

Pressing the "print" screen button on the keyboard brings up the interface to click Capture.

## Current Limitations

According to a recent GitHub issue from November [REDACTED_PHONE], there are some challenges with the clipboard workflow:

- cosmic-screenshot forces UI interaction, requiring users to click capture after grabbing the screen area
- Users seeking a direct-to-clipboard workflow (similar to macOS's cmd-shift-4) have been using custom scripts with tools like `grim`, `slurp`, and `wl-copy`

All key bindings can be modified in COSMIC Settings (Input devices > Keyboard > Keyboard shortcuts).

The search results suggest that while COSMIC has screenshot capabilities for selective areas, the direct-to-clipboard workflow may require custom configuration or third-party tools rather than a single built-in keyboard shortcut.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

results:
Based on the search results, here's what I found about COSMIC desktop screenshot keyboard shortcuts for selective area to clipboard:

## Screenshot Functionality

COSMIC's screenshot tool can take screenshots of the entire screen, a specific window, or a selected area.

## Keyboard Shortcuts

There is an existing default hotkey: shift + ctrl + print for screenshot functionality, though this was noted as inconvenient.

Pressing the "print" screen button on the keyboard brings up the interface to click Capture.

## Current Limitations

According to a recent GitHub issue from November [REDACTED_PHONE], there are some challenges with the clipboard workflow:

- cosmic-screenshot forces UI interaction, requiring users to click capture after grabbing the screen area
- Users seeking a direct-to-clipboard workflow (similar to macOS's cmd-shift-4) have been using custom scripts with tools like `grim`, `slurp`, and `wl-copy`

All key bindings can be modified in COSMIC Settings (Input devices > Keyboard > Keyboard shortcuts).

The search results suggest that while COSMIC has screenshot capabilities for selective areas, the direct-to-clipboard workflow may require custom configuration or third-party tools rather than a single built-in keyboard shortcut.

content.thinking: Okay, so cosmic-screenshot seems to be the tool, but it doesn't have a direct "copy to clipboard" option. Based on the search results, it seems that the default shortcut brings up the UI, and users have been requesting a direct-to-clipboard workflow. Let me provide the user with the information I found.

content.text:
Based on my research, the default COSMIC screenshot shortcut is **Shift + Ctrl + Print** (or **Shift + Ctrl + PrtSc**), which opens the screenshot interface where you can select an area and choose to capture it.

However, according to recent GitHub discussions, COSMIC's screenshot tool currently requires clicking "Capture" after selecting the area, and doesn't have a built-in direct-to-clipboard shortcut for selective screenshots yet. 

You can check and customize your keyboard shortcuts by opening **COSMIC Settings** → **Input devices** → **Keyboard** → **Keyboard shortcuts**.

If you need direct-to-clipboard functionality, you might need to set up a custom shortcut using tools like `grim` and `slurp` with `wl-copy` (Wayland clipboard tool).

Sources:
- [Pop!_OS [REDACTED_PHONE] LTS COSMIC Keyboard Shortcuts - System76 Support](https://support.system76.com/articles/pop-cosmic-keyboard-shortcuts/)
- [Add keyboard shortcut for copying screenshot of an area to clipboard · Issue #249 · pop-os/cosmic](https://github.com/pop-os/cosmic/issues/249)
- [Custom keyboard shortcuts don't work · Issue #[REDACTED_PHONE] · pop-os/cosmic-epoch](https://github.com/pop-os/cosmic-epoch/issues/[REDACTED_PHONE])

content.thinking:
I can see the desktop file. Currently it has:
- Exec=btop
- Terminal=true

To make it open in alacritty specifically, I need to:
1. Create a local override in ~/.local/share/applications/btop.desktop
2. Change the Exec line to: Exec=alacritty -e btop
3. Set Terminal=false (since we're launching the terminal ourselves)

I should create this in the user's local applications directory rather than modifying the system file.

content.text: I'll create a local override for the btop++ launcher to use alacritty. This way your custom settings won't be overwritten by system updates.

content.thinking: Good, the directory exists. Now I'll write the modified desktop file to the local applications directory.

input.content:
[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Version=1.0
Name=btop++
GenericName=System Monitor
GenericName[it]=Monitor di sistema
GenericName[zh_TW]=系統監視器
Comment=Resource monitor that shows usage and stats for processor, memory, disks, network and processes
Comment[it]=Monitoraggio delle risorse: mostra utilizzo e statistiche per CPU, dischi, rete e processi
Comment[zh_TW]=顯示處理器、主記憶體、磁碟、網路與進程的使用與統計數據的資源監視器應用程式
Icon=btop
Exec=alacritty -e btop
Terminal=false
Categories=System;Monitor;ConsoleOnly;
Keywords=system;process;task
Keywords[zh_TW]=系統;進程;處理程序;任務

content.text:
Done! I've modified the btop++ launcher to open in alacritty. The changes are:
- Created a local override at `~/.local/share/applications/btop.desktop`
- Changed `Exec=btop` to `Exec=alacritty -e btop`

content.thinking: Good, I've updated both files to use sudo -E, which will run them with admin privileges while preserving environment variables (similar to the antigravity-admin wrapper). Now I should update the desktop database.
Done! Both launchers have been updated to run with sudo -E, which will run them with admin privileges while preserving environment variables.

content.text:
Done! Both launchers now run with sudo (admin privileges):

**Claude Code**: `alacritty -e sudo -E /usr/bin/claude`
**Gemini CLI**: `alacritty -e sudo -E gemini`

The `-E` flag preserves your environment variables when running with sudo. When you launch either app from the menu, you'll be prompted for your password (if needed) before the application starts in alacritty.
